title: Contributing
text: awardFindR built easily extendable include additional data sources welcome contributions adding support additional databases research funding. Adding new source involves three steps: 1. Adding sourcename.R file parse database using API webscraping discussed 2. Adding source default sources argument search_awards() function main.R 3. Adding relevant tests

title: Contributing
text: New sources entirely self-contained single .R file. Sources need minimum two functions: get_* function scrapes raw data source returns -, hidden .standardize_* (note preceding period) function harmonizes data fit data.frame output search_awards(). file containing source easily identifiable filename, reflected naming get_* standardize_* functions. example, import “Megafunds Foundation” megafunds.R, containing get_megafunds() .standardize_megafunds().

title: Contributing
text: get_* routine exported, end users can call directly interest specific data source. faithful reproduction original data source possible, though variables still R-friendly (example, award amounts strings like “$300,000” aren’t useful. integer 300000 much useful.) routines usually use HTML JSON-based HTTP resources. utils.R package request() function handles HTTP POST GET requests httr returns xml2 objects (can used rvest xml2) json base R list() object automatically. order centralize HTTP error handling standardize message output user, please employ function much possible HTTP requests.

title: Contributing
text: function can largely tailored needs API, follow basic style guidelines. Three arguments required: Keyword date date function accept least one keyword two date terms arguments. keyword string, , source can handle one keyword time, keywords vector strings. Dates typically exact days years, depending capabilities search function available source. Exact dates date objects named from_date to_date, years integers named from_year to_year. Additional source-specific variables can added function, default values specified. *_get routines function expected three variables alone. possible, searching done server-side reduce HTTP traffic. Downloading whole grant database searching grep() similar function last resort. also minimizes CPU load. JSON sources shouldn’t need additional dependencies, since request() function handles encoding decoding /lists automatically. HTML/XML sources, however, use rvest xml2, respectively. source use HTML, XML JSON, may necessary employ additional dependencies necessary. extreme case done care.

title: Contributing
text: awardFindR calls internal.*_standardize function, turn call get_* function described . .standardize_* functions need accept exact input. includes: keywords - vector keywords search from_date - beginning date object (e.g. “2015-01-01”) end_date - ending date object date objects translated whatever source-specific requirements search terms. API can delineate searches year, get year. API can handle one keyword time, loop function multiple keywords lapply(). function needs return data.frame following columns: institution - Institution name pi - Principal investigator name year - Award year start - Award start date end - Award end date program - Program department name amount - Award amount (US dollars) id - Award ID number (way uniquely identifying duplicates one source) title - Project title description keyword - searched keyword returned result source - source result came

title: Contributing
text: Source routines included search_awards() function sources argument. Include name new source (section “_standardize”) default value sources search_awards() main.R. include new source routine default functionality, expose name documentation users likely discover .

title: Contributing
text: main tests test-full.R attempt exercise successful results code branches. latter always works. Unfortunately, default search former (terms “qualitative analysis” “ethnography” 2018) actually return results smaller sources. reasons, ’s good idea create source-specific test .standardize_* function. Tests actually return results, also minimally tax API. Less 10 results ideal. one exception : source needs loop multiple pages. case, smallest number results triggers looping ideal, order ensure maximum test coverage. One test verify reproducibility; .e. get results query specified date range. used real-world HTTP resource, alert us change resource provided. Finally, HTTP requests tests cached using ROpenSci package vcr. Individual sources cassettes. limits stress APIs frequent testing internal logic, especially continuous integration system. Failure potentially result service-level bans ’re careful.

title: awardFindR
awardFindR
code:
nsf <- search_awards(keywords="illicit", sources="nsf", from_date="2023-01-01") str(nsf) #> 'data.frame': 20 obs. of 12 variables: #> $ institution: chr "University of Tennessee Knoxville" "Dartmouth College" "The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees" "George Mason University" ... #> $ pi : chr "Wang, Zhenbo" "Zhang, Xiaojing (John)" "Yao, Fan" "El-Amine, Hadi" ... #> $ year : chr "2023" "2023" "2024" "2023" ... #> $ start : chr "2023-04-01" "2023-09-01" "2024-03-01" "2023-01-01" ... #> $ end : chr "2024-07-31" "2026-08-31" "2029-02-28" "2023-12-31" ... #> $ program : chr "47.070" "47.041" "47.070" "47.041" ... #> $ amount : chr "150000.00" "399541.00" "556875.00" "79773.00" ... #> $ id : chr "2231710" "2318814" "2340777" "2247286" ... #> $ title : chr "SCC-PG: Securing Underserved Communities from Drug Abuse with Drone-Based Smart Medication Delivery" "Label-free Detection of Opioids in Liquid Using Zinc Oxide Nanophotonic Sensor" "CAREER: Understanding and Ensuring Secure-by-design Microarchitecture in Modern Era of Computing" "Conference and Grantee's Meeting: Disrupting Operations of Illicit Supply Networks; Arlington, Virginia; 27-28 March 2023" ... #> $ abstract : chr "Despite considerable efforts in combating substance use and exploring novel treatment and recovery strategies, "| __truncated__ "Illicit drug abuse has become another major national health crisis since the Covid-19
pandemic started, due"| __truncated__ "Microarchitectural attacks (i.e., side and covert channels) have opened a new chapter in computer system securi"| __truncated__ "Networks that illegally traffic in everything from people and drugs to human organs and nuclear material pose s"| __truncated__ ... #> $ keyword : chr "illicit" "illicit" "illicit" "illicit" ... #> $ source : chr "NSF" "NSF" "NSF" "NSF" ...

what: Multiple sources and keywords, specific date range
title: awardFindR
text: keywords, can specify external simple csv file. specify .csv file path keywords, file list keywords, one string per line. example:
code: nsf_and_nih <- search_awards(keywords=c("ontological", "audio recordings"), sources=c("nsf", "nih"), from_date="2018-01-01", to_date="2018-02-01") table(nsf_and_nih$source) #> < table of extent 0 > unique(nsf_and_nih$keyword) #> NULL qualitative data qualitative analysis case study case studies

title: awardFindR
text: awardFindR framework scrapes searches variety grant award databases specific keywords. include major US federal agencies like NSF NIH well private organizations like Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation. Results searching databases collected made available users. package designed modular extensible, supporting number APIs web-based sources provide award data available online. Packages provided similar functionality include awardsBot.

title: awardFindR
text: Install awardFindR directly repository using remotes package

title: awardFindR
text: Arnold Ventures (arnold) Carnegie Corporation New York (carnegie) Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (gates) MacArthur Foundation (macarthur) Mellon Foundation (mellon) NIH RePORTER (nih) National Science Foundation (nsf) Open Philanthropy (ophil) Open Society Foundations (osociety) Rockefeller Foundation (rockefeller) Russell Sage Foundation (rsf) Robert Wood Johnson Foundation (rwjf) Alfred P. Sloan Foundation (sloan) Social Science Research Council (ssrc) John Templeton Foundation (templeton) USASpending.gov (usaspend)

title: awardFindR
text: search_awards parameters change keywords, sources dates search criteria, passed source routines. Dates interpreted varying degrees precision based data available source. See included help individual sources understand respective limitations. Individual sources functions . get_nsf specifically fetches results NSF, get_nih fetches results NIH, example. meant provide end users higher levels detail ’re interested specific source.

title: awardFindR
text: Search awards matching keyword since default cutoff Jan 1, 2019 today See included vignette additional examples. interested results specific source, source function. example, someone interested NSF results “ethnography” 2018 2020 run following: Similar functions exist supported source. See included help details, arguments differ slightly .

awardFindR grant search — search_awards
text: Query collection online grant databases awards. queries can limited keyword, source date terms.

title: awardFindR grant search — search_awards
code: search_awards(   keywords,   sources = c("arnold", "carnegie", "gates", "macarthur", "mellon", "nih", "nsf",     "ophil", "osociety", "rockefeller", "rsf", "rwjf", "sloan", "ssrc", "templeton",     "usaspend"),   from_date = "2019-01-01",   to_date = Sys.Date(),   verbose = FALSE )

title: awardFindR grant search — search_awards
text: keywords Path keywords csv file (1 term per line) vector. sources vector sources pull . Default: from_date date object limit search, defaults Jan 1 2019 to_date date object limit search, defaults today verbose enable verbose HTTP messages. TRUE/FALSE, default: false

title: awardFindR grant search — search_awards
text: data.frame

title: awardFindR grant search — search_awards
code: # Results for "ethnography" from NSF between 1/1 and 2/1 2020 if (FALSE) awards <- search_awards("ethnography", "nsf", "2020-01-01", "2020-02-01")  # More intensive queries if (FALSE) { # Specific keywords, all sources: specific <- search_awards(keywords=c("ethnography", "case studies"))  # Specific keyword, all sources, specific date range: five_years <- search_awards(keywords="qualitative", from_date="2015-01-01", to_date="2020-01-01") }

title: Version 1.0.1
text: Instead extracting 2020s csv NEH, use actual API
